STAUNTON \emdash Anna Katherine (Miller) Nuckols, 89, widow of Phil Bryant Nuckols, of 50 Evans Lane, died Monday, Sept. 16, 2013, at her residence.

She was born May 28, 1924, in Augusta County, a daughter of the late Harry M. and Ophelia (Arehart) Miller.

Prior to retirement, she worked for ASR.

She was a member of Mint Spring United Methodist Church and the VFW Post #2216 Ladies Auxiliary.

Family members include two sons and daughters-in-law, Ray B. and Nancye Nuckols of Vesuvius and Bruce and Beth Nuckols of Chesterfield County; a daughter and son-in-law, Kay and Maurice Smith of Staunton; six grandchildren and nine great-grandchildren.In addition to her husband, she was preceded in death by her son, Phil M. Nuckols and two brothers, Murray M. Miller and Edward L. Miller.

A funeral service will be at 1:30 p.m. Thursday, Sept. 19, 2013, at Mint Spring United Methodist Church by the Rev. Terry Clark. Burial will follow in Augusta Memorial Park.Active pallbearers will be Cary Arehart, Doug Cox, Glenn Shickel, Stephen Shickel, Sonny Miller, Charlie Barnes and Roger Patterson.The family will receive friends from 6 until 8 p.m. Wednesday, Sept. 18, 2013, in the Henry Funeral Home.Memorials may be made to Mint Spring United Methodist Church Building Fund c/o Ronnie Arehart, P.O. Box 14, Mint Spring, VA 24463.Condolences may be sent to the family at www.henryfuneralhome.net.

[DI15761] Betty Jo Pauley, 82, of South Point, OH passed away Wednesday, July 20, 2011, in Heartland of Riverview, South Point, OH. She was born May 5, 1929 in Putnam County, WV a daughter of the late Hoyt Luther and Lula Virginia Nuckles Williams. She was a homemaker

Her husband, Dennis Pauleya brother, Hoyt Lee Williams, also preceded her in death.Survivors include:three daughters and a son-in-law, Brenda and Pat Leighty of South Point, OH,DeEtta Leonard of South Point, Ohio,Danette Pauley-Holstein of Huntington, WV;

four grandchildren, Ronda Franklin and her husband, Martin, Patrick Leighty and his wife, Jessica, Tonya Dean and her husband, Stacy and Courtney Ferrell;nine great grandchildren, Kayla and Brenna Childers, Ryan Leighty, Baileigh and Brayden Dean, John Ryan Billups, Taylor Leighty, Bethany and BreAnna Franklin;a brother and sister-in-law, J.T. and Louise Williams of Proctorville, OH;a host of nieces and nephews.

Funeral service at Chapman's Mortuary, Huntington, with Pastor Ric Frazier, and Pastor Ricky Kirk officiating. Burial in Woodmere Memorial Park, Huntington.

[DI15796] Margaret G. Knuckles

Margaret Goldene Knuckles, 81, of Lamar died Monday, March 13, 2006, at Countryside Manor Nursing Home. She was a daughter of the late Benjiman Huff and Bertha Jones Johnson, member of Lamar Baptist Church, retired from Tyson Foods of Clarksville, and was preceded in death by one daughter, Mary Knuckles; and three brothers, Morris, Johnny and Orvil Johnson. Survivors include her husband, Marvin Henry Knuckles; one daughter, Velma Dean White of Russellville; three sons, Benny Edward Knuckles of Fairfield, Calif., Marvin Leon Knuckles of Hot Springs, and Joe Knuckles of Lama r; two sisters, Francis Ward of Bee Branch and Jewell Waldrop of Atkins; one sister-in-law, Beatrice Johnson of Lamar; and ten grandchildren. Funer al will be at 11 a.m. Friday, March 17, at Roller-Cox Funeral Home Chap el with Rev. Billy Milam officiating. Burial will be in Lamar Cemetery.

Pallbearers will be Marvin Johnson, Vernon White, Glen Hickey, Maynard Gor don, Paul Milner, and Jimmy Campbell. Visitation will be from 6-8 p.m. Thu rsday, March 16, at Roller-Cox Funeral Home.

[NI15836] Terited Colonel in the Air Force. Active duty for 18 years, including WW II and later served as commander of the USAF Reserve Training Center in Louisville. Upon leaving the military he became a history professor at the University of Kentucky. His children were born in six different countries and are married to five different nationalities.

[DI15836] Lexington Herald-Leader (KY) - July 15, 1993

Deceased Name: PINEVILLE -- Thomas Calloway Knuckles

PINEVILLE -- Thomas Calloway Knuckles, 74, formerly of Bird Branch, retir ed Air Force lieutenant colonel and former University of Kentucky Engli sh and history instructor, widower of Ruth Wheatley Knuckles, died Tuesda y. Services 2 p.m. Sunday, Pinelawn Memorial Cemetery. No visitation. Arnett & Steele Funeral Home in charge. Contributions suggested to one's favorite charity

Col. Thomas Calloway Knuckles, 74, passed away Tuesday July 13 1993 in Far ifield, Ohio. He was born March 7 1919 at Field, Kentucky a son of the late Millard F Knuckles and Lydia Green Knuckles. He was a retired United St ates Air Force Colonel and a retired professor from the Univ of Ky where he taught English and history. He was a member of the Union College Alu mni Assoc. In addition to his parents, he was preceded by his wife, Ruth Wheatley Knuckles. Survivors include four sons, Douglas Knuckles, Tampa Florida, Julian Knuckles and Ian Knuckles, both of Mexico City, Mexico and Ken Knuckles, Canterburg, England; four daughters, Jennifer Knuckles, Lond on England, Augusta Fretwell, Bracknell England, Clare Knuckles, Kent Engl and and Katherine Knuckles, Noston, Mass; a host of grandchildren and great grandchildren; four brothers, Franklin Knuckles, Bird Brach, James Knuckles, Altlanta Georgia and Paul Knuckles, Covington Ky and one sister, Ruby Myers of Phoenix Arizona. Graveside services were Sunday at Linelawn Me morial Gardens with the Rev Thea O Carter presiding. Arnett and Steele Fun eral Home in charge of arrangements.

[DI15837] KNUCKLES, Or. James OR. JAMES O. KNUCKLES At age 89, Dr. James O. Knuckles, of Atlanta~ formerly of Knoxville. passed away August 7, 2010 at Peachtree Christian Hospice, Duluth. GA. Or. Knuckles was born on March 2, 1921 in Bell County Kentucky. the son of Millard F. and Lydia Green Knuckles. parents of 6 boys and 3 girls. Dr. Knuckles attended Union College (KY), University of Tennessee (Knoxville), Teachers College of Columbia Unitersity (NYC). and Peabody College of Vanderbilt University (Nashville. TN) earning a BS degree in Science. MS degree in Education and EdD. Doctorate «i»in «/i»Educational Administration. Over a span of 50 working years, Dr. Knuckles served as a teacher in a one-room school. an elementary Junior High and Senior High teacher, college professor, High School Principal. Director of Instruction for a City-County School System ·and as a Superintendent of public schoots and. as the Administrator of Federal Programs for the Atlanta School System. After the "Day of Infamy' at Pearl Harbor; Dr. Knuckles became a pilot and served in the Naval Air Corps. Later in 1944. he requested and was granted a transfer to the U. S. Army Air Force, with overall time of service of 48 months for World War II. He was happiest when serving his country, his church, his chosen work of public education, and his community. His «i»many «/i»friends admired and respected him. Dr. Knuckles lived. served, and died a dedicated Christian gentleman. Dr. Jim Knuckles was a working supporting member of the Christian Church (Disciples of Christ) and an adult Sunday school teacher for over 50 years. He

held every elected office in his church. His peers honored him by electing him to be an Elder Emeritus of his church. Also, his peers (at the Regional Church level), the Christian Men"s Fellowship Commission presented Dr. Jim with a beautiful plaque as the Outstanding Christian layman (Georgia Region) for· 1997. Jim Knuckles was preceded in death by his wife of over 50 years, Elizabeth, his only son, David, grand children Christine and· Rob Hugueley, sister Ruby Meyers of Phoenix. AZ and brother Franklin Knuckles of Pineville! KY. He is survived by family: Suzanne Elizabeth Hugueley, Of Atlanta, Georgia; Kathy and husband, James A Harris and children, Cole, Cody, Cameron and Christina of Knoxville, brother Paul K of Roswell GA, Cecil K of Detroit.

[NI15839] Married Lloyd Mason Thomas, had daugher Donna Lee DLTS1950@yahoo.com. Loyd son of Ledford Thomas and Una Angel. Information sent to Fredwyn for book.

Roberta, the daughter of Millard and Lydia Knuckles, was born on January 31, 1925, in Wasioto, Kentucky. Roberta always said that as a young girl she was a tomboy. She attended Bell County High School where she played the flute in the band. During her high school years, she was chosen as anattendant for the Mountain laurel Festival. On July 28, 1942, in Detroit, Michigan, Roberta married lloyd Mason Thomas. Della Knuckles Doan and Paris Doan were the witnesses. Roberta was 17 and lloyd was 22. They most likely eloped. The marriage certificate states that Roberta was 21. lloyd and Roberta had known each other for a long time. Lloyd worked in Millard Knuckles' store and also attended Bell County High School. In addition, Roberta's brothers, James Oscar and Brown Lee, were lloyd's good friends. lloyd and Oscar attended Sunday School together and enjoyed singing together. lloyd Thomas was born in Trace Fork, Kentucky, on May 23, 1920. His parents were Ledford Thomas and Una Angle. ( I am not sure if the spelling is Angle or Angel. In my Thomas family Bible, it is spelled Angle.) Ledford Thomas was a coal miner, a hard worker, and a good man. Una Angle deserted her husband and children when lloyd was a small child. lloyd was a Boy Scout, attended Sunday School faithfully, and loved to sing and to play baseball. After their marriage, lloyd and Roberta remained in Detroit. lloyd worked in a factory. Lloyd hadcontracted polio as a small child, which left him with a limp. Because ofthe limp, he was declared 4-F and was unable to join the military. Roberta also worked in a factory for a time. They were still living in Detroit when, on November 17, 1943, their daughter, Donna Lee, was born. Because Roberta had a respiratory condition that was not improving, on the advice of her doctor, in 1945, she and lloyd and Donna moved to Phoenix, Arizona. Phoenix was to be their home for many years to come. Not long after arriving in Phoenix, lloyd and Roberta found lodging at the Far West Auto Court. During WW II, there was a housing shortage in Phoenix. Eventually, they earned the trust of the owner and became the managers of Far West Auto Court. lloyd also began working at Reynolds Aluminum Company along with holding a part-time job at a dry cleaners. Lloyd worked for Reynolds Aluminum until he retired in 1980. His job title was tube tool repairman.

In time, Lloyd and Roberta were in a position to buy their first home. Since lloyd was very handy, he made all the improvements to their new home himself. In a few years, they sold this home, purchased another, fixed it up, sold it, purchased another, and so on. With each sale, they were able to make a modest profit. Roberta and Lloyd were always devoted and loving partners who worked together shoulder-to-shoulder. During this period, Roberta learned to sew and made many of her own clothes as well as Donna's.

A by-product of buying, fixing up, and selling their homes was that Roberta became interested in selling real estate. She decided to become a licensed real estate agent and in time became a real estate broker. As it turned out, she was a natural-born sales person and was very successful. When she and

'Lloyd-moved to Wickenburg (about 30 miles from Phoenix) in the 1970's, she opened her own real estate office which she called Desert Casas Realty.lloyd and Roberta were very devout Christians. They were members of Capital Christian Church(Disciples of Christ) in Phoenix for many years. Lloyd served as a deacon and was eventually elected tobe Chairman of the Board of Directors of the church. Lloyd also was the catcher on the church baseball team. (Donna was the team scorekeeper.) Roberta served as a Sunday School teacher and was the sponsor of one of the church youth groups. Donna was also very involved in church activities and youth groups. She held offices within her local church youth group as well as offices on the state youth group level. Donna also sang in the chOir, played the piano and organ in church, and taught a Sunday School class. Roberta Thomas passed away in Phoenix on S,!!ptember 1, 1980, at the age of 55. Her life was cut short by the respiratory condition she had bravely fought and endured since her youth. lloyd Mason Thomas passed away in Phoenix on March 21, 1990, at the age of 69. His passing was due to heart disease.

[DI15840] Born feb. 14, 1927, in Pineville, Kentucky, Ruby passed away peacefully on Dec. 25, 2009, in Surprise, Arizona, at the age of 82. The daughter of Lydia Green Knuckles and Millard Filmore Knuckles, Ruby was preceded in death by her parents and by six of her sisters and brothers: Della Doan, Roberta Thomas, Thomas C. Knuckles, Brown Lee Knuckles, and franklin D. Knuckles. Ruby also endured the loss of her infant daughter, Patricia Kaye Myers in 1950, her husband, John Stanley Myers in 1965, and her son, John Steven Myers in early 2009. Ruby leaves behind three brothers: Charles C. Knuckles of Michigan, and Dr. James O. Knuckles and Paul Knuckles, both of Georgia, as well as numerous nieces and nephews. Ruby accepted Christ and became a member of Capital Christian Church in Phoenix in 1947. She attended Lamson Business College in 1947-48 and in the years that followed, pursued various other courses of study. In 1972, she graduated with high distinction from Glendale Community College with an Associate of Arts degree. In 1948, Ruby married her beloved husband Johnny, who was serving in the U.S. Army. Ruby was able

to join Johnny when he was stationed in Japan in the «i»1950's «/i»and in France in the 1960's. Over the years, they were also stationed in San Francisco at the Presidio and in various locations in Virginia, Kentucky, and Pennsylvania. During several periods of her life, Ruby lived in Phoenix with her sister and brotherin- law, Roberta and Lloyd Thomas. In 1965, after the untimely passing of her husband, Ruby, along with her son Steve, relocated to Phoenix in order to be near her sister and brother-in-law.

After settling in Phoenix, Ruby developed a serious interest in and expert knowledge of Native American arts and crafts. This expertise led to a very fulfilling career in the marketing and sale of Native American handicrafts. At various times in Phoenix, she worked for Godber's, Gilbert Ortega, and the Camelback Inn. In Yellowstone National Park, she worked for Hamilton Stores and for the Yellowstone Park Company. While with the Yellowstone Park Company, she served as a dorm supervisor, and she was promoted to gift shop manager. Ruby also worked at the Grand Teton Lodge and in Jackson Hole, Wyoming. An avid reader, Ruby read books on a wide range of topics. She especially liked louie L'amour and other western authors. Ruby enjoyed music, especially Country and Western, and had a large collection of LP's, cassette tapes, and CD's. John Denver was one of her favorites. Her favorite movies were Dances with Wolves and Lonesome Dove. She treasured her collection of stuffed animals. She loved the bears the best - especially one she called "Gus the Grizzly." Ruby always enjoyed the o!!t-of-doors and had a deep love and appreciation of the beauty and grandeur of nature. She was an amatuer geologist and a rock hound. She enjoyed picnics and barbeques and was always ready for a hike. Ruby liked hiking the trails of the White Tank Mountains, and she was proud to have climbed to the summit of Squaw Peak. The photographs Ruby took over the years of landscapes in Arizona and Wyoming demonstrate her talent as a photographer. Ruby had a style of her own. She was usually seen wearing blue jeans, a casual shirt, a tooled leather cowboy belt or Concho belt, pieces of turquoise and silver Native American jewelry, and, now and then, even her cowboy boots. Ruby had a gentle, kind, unassuming manner and an amusing sense of humor. She was a loving Wife, mother, sister, and aunt as well as a valued friend. She will be greatly missed by her family and friends.

A graveside memorial service will be held for Ruby at the Wickenburg Cemetery at 1:00 p.m. on Saturday, Jqnuary 23, 2009.

[DI15842] Franklin Delano Knuckles, 78 passed away on Sunday, June 21, 2009 at Tri-State Health and Rehabilitation Center in Harrogate. He was born in Bird Branch on November 21, 1931 a son of the late Millard Fillmore and Lydia Greene Knuckles. Frank was a graduate of Bell County High School and Harlan County Vocational-Electrical School. He was a veteran of the United States Air Force and had been a heavy equipment operator and an electrician, and was the co-owner of M & K Electric.

In addition to his parents he was preceded in death by brothers and sisters, Della Doan, Thomas Calloway Knuckles, Roberta Thomas and Brown Lee Knuckles.

He is survived by his wife of fifty three and a half years, Mildred Garrett Knuckles of Pineville; children, Douglas Lee Knuckles and wife Terri of Harrogate, Donald Wade Knuckles of Lexington, and Jennifer Lynn Smith and husband Scott of Laurel Hill; grandchildren, Benjamin Douglas, Patrick Aaron, Margaret Michelle "Maggie", Dillon Asher, Brenden James, Ashlynn Greer, Ian Dennis, Kayla Michelle, Matthew Blake, Caleb Scott and Alexandria Grace "Alli"; brothers and sisters, James Oscar Knuckles of Atlanta, Ruby Mae Myers of Phoenix, AZ, Charles Cecil Knuckles of Burton, MI and Paul Letcher Knuckles of Atlanta; and a host of cousins, nieces, nephews, other relatives and many, many friends.

Deceased Name: Richard (Dick) T. Nuckols

COCOA, FL- -- Mr. Richard (Dick) Thomas Nuckols, 90, formerly of Spartanbu rg, died Thursday, August 18, 2005 at his home in Cocoa, FL. He was born J une 5, 1915 in Atlanta, GA, a son of the late Frederick Nuckols, Sr. and D oris Timberlake Nuckols. He was retired from Butler Shoe Company after ma ny years of service and was a M/Sgt. in the U.S. Army and a Veteran of Wor ld War II, having served in Pattons 3rd Army Division and fought in the Ba ttle of the Bulge. Surviving are his wife, Juanita Prince Nuckols; two nie ces, Elizabeth N. Williams of Spartanburg and Carolyn Wenige of Westminste r, MD; and a nephew, Ron Elmore of Greenville. He was predeceased by two s isters, Mildred Nuckols and Dorothy Elmore; and a brother, Frederick Nucko ls, Jr. Graveside services will be held 11:00 a.m. Wednesday, August 24, 2 005 at Greenlawn Memorial Gardens, conducted by the Rev. Michael Hensley. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be made to a charity of ones choice.An o nline guest register is available at www.floydmortuary.com. Floyds Greenla wn Chapel

Of these four sons, William, Jeremiah, and James chose to use the surna me NICHOLS, while their brother Robert used the surname NUCKLES. Robert NI CHOLS/NUCKLES (the father) is found with both surnames in court documen ts in Amherst County VA, whereas he is listed as NICHOLS in his will in 1826 in Mercer County KY. I put this down to illiteracy (both on the pa rt of Robert and those who wrote the documents). There is a series of la nd transfers in Amherst County VA, in which Robert and his wife Fanny (Whitten) buy out the inheritance of her sistersthe other daughters of Jeremi ah WHITTEN, in which Robert is called NUCKLES. However, his two marriage records in Amherst County list him as NICHOLS. I believe that this Robert NICHOLS/NUCKLES is a grandson of Howard CASH of Amherst County VA per Howard Cash's 1773 will in that county, in which he mentions a daughter Elizabeth NICKLAS.

In the name of God Amen. I Robert Nichols of the county of Mercer and state of Kentucky finding my days are drawing to a close but in my perfect senses, do make this my last will and Testament in manner following. I desire that all my first debts be paid for the purpose subject my whole Esta te both real and personal I give & bequeath to my wife Fanny Nicles my negro woman Susanah and one negroe named Chips & sixty acres of land includi ng my Dwelling house and other necessary buildings sentible thereto--the l and to be laid off suitable so as to give her timber sufficient to suppo rt the place. I give her two horses such as she may make choice of wi th as much of every kind of all my other stock as she may see proper to ke ep, as much household & kitchen furniture & farming utensils as she wish es to keep during her natural life.. I Devise to my son William Nicho ls on negroe boy named John & seventy acres of land including the place wh ere he now lives to be laid off in a manner most suitable so as not to int erfere with the other land I give to my other sons. I devise to my son Jer emiah Nichols one negroe boy named Powell, seventy-six acres of land inclu ding the place he settled & formerly lived on. I devise to my son Robert Nichols one negroe boy named Dick & seventy-six acres of land including t he place he now lives on. I devise to my son James Nichols one negroe gi rl named Sally and sixty-two acres of land adjoining his mother's land & at my wife decease he is to have the land I give to her. I desire th at my wife shall keep possesion of James's land and negroe until he is twe nty-one years of age, unless he gets married before. I further desire th at my son James shall have a horse, saddle & Bridle as near the value of t hat I gave my other sons as can be made so soon as he shall need them, all so one cow & calf, two sheep, one sow & pigs, two fat hogs equal to tho se given to my other sons, also one bed & furniture. I desire that the bal ance of my personal property shall be sold & equally divided amongst my ch ildren after so much shall be taken therefrom as will be sufficient to p ay for schooling James one year. I do hereby appoint my beloved wife Fanny Nichols and my son William Nichols executors of this my will with joi nt & separate powers for carrying the same into effect in witness where of I hereunto set my hand & seal this 14th day of Feby one thousand eight hundred twenty-six.

Witness

Dr. John J. Dickey Diary, Fleming County, Ky. Recorded in the 1870's a nd beyond. Reprinted in Kentucky Explorer, Volume 11, No.10, April, 199 7, p. 80. By permission. Clay County.

THE ASHER Family (BY John W. Culton, of Clay County, KY.) I marked the fir st sawed log above the Cumberland Falls. This was in 1874. There bei ng no railway crossing the Cumberland River above the falls, rafts could n ot be taken over the falls hence there was no market for the timber. T he Southern Pump Company built a boom below the mouth of Rockcastle Rive r, caught the timber, rafted it, and took it to Nashville. The Indian Lum ber Company was interested in the boom as they also bought logs. In 18 75 or 1876 an ice tide swept the boom away breaking the companies and crip pling me. A boom between Barbourville and Pineville had been built. He re logs were caught and at a certain stages of water, were

turned loose. The ice tide swept this away also. The ice pil ed up to 45 feet high. The breaking away was like the firing of artiller y. If the boom had not given away the whole country would have been inund ated. The first timber I marketed was walnut. I bought walnut trees 45 i nches in diamater for $2.00 apiece. I cut thousands of walnut logs on t he
